content.question: A chi-square goodness-of-fit test where all assumptions were met yielded the test statistic <math alttext="chi square equals 12.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>12.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Henry claims the corresponding <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value of 0.03 means that the probability of observing a test statistic of <math alttext="chi square equals 12.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>12.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is 0.03, assuming the null hypothesis is true. Which of the following is a valid criticism of this interpretation of the <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value?

choices.label: The null hypothesis can never be assumed to be true.
The null hypothesis is not stated.
The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value is not the probability of observing 12.4 exactly.
The significance level is not stated.
The degrees of freedom are not stated.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value is not the probability of observing 12.4 exactly.
